commentary.line: That's it from us. Thanks for your company. Join us back tomorrow as India take on West Indies in Perth. Goodbye.
Let's take a look at some of the interesting tweets pertaining to this game:
@cricketaakash: Good win for Bangladesh...pre quarterfinal with England lined up next. Should be fun. #ChaseCricket with @AltoK10
@cricket_U 23: Only 2nd time that four Bangladesh batsmen have scored 50s in the same ODI. #cwc15
@mohanstatsman: England 2 pts need to win their next 2 games v Ban & Afg to qualify with 6 pts Bangladesh 5 pts need to win atleast one vs Eng or NZ #CWC15
@bhogleharsha: Good to see man of the match award going to Kyle Coetzer. Too often we give too much weightage to the player from the winning side.

Mortaza: "Boys have done really well, especially batters, really happy. Tamim (Iqbal) was outstanding, (Mahmudullah) Riyad, Mushfiqur (Rahim), Shakib (Al Hasan) and (Sabbir) Rahman were brilliant. Still our bowlers haven't bowled well, but it's a good thing that the batters got runs before the big games. We will try our level best to play well in all three departments. We still have two chances, so hopefully we will try our best against England, if not against New Zealand."

Mommsen: "Very tough to take, especially after the last result. I think we did a lot of things right today, but unfortunately we couldn't put the whole package together. We were happy, we always knew it was a good wicket, so we still needed to go out there and bowl well, put the ball in good areas and try and create some chances. Unfortunately, we couldn't create enough chances to take 10 wickets out there. I was trying my best to keep things fresh and keep the batters guessing, but credit to them, they actually batted really well and managed the innings really well. It's a huge moment for the team. Brilliant innings, I was fortunate enough to be out there for most of that acceleration period (talking about Coetzer's knock). And some of the strokes that he was playing were brilliant to see, because we know what he's capable of. So, a huge moment for him and a huge moment for the team. Hopefully, people back home will be proud. We had a bit of time off after that Afghanistan game. We came back refreshed. We had some really good training sessions. I think we were out for today, definitely and that showed in the first half, but unfortunately it was not to be. Throughout the four games so far we've showed that we are capable of playing good cricket. It's just a case of us playing good cricket for a longer time now. Two very tough games to come, but that's all the more exciting and something that we are very much looking forward to."

Coetzer: "Not the way we wanted to end the game. We were just not able to create pressure to pick up a few wickets. I think we would have taken that score at the start of the day. Like I said, we just needed to create a bit of pressure, we didn't get many opportunities to pick up those wickets. There were a couple of run-out chances maybe, but other than that I thought they batted really well. It's been nice to score a few runs but at the end of the day, it's the end result of the game and that's just a bit disappointing today. Maybe, we would have liked to get to 330, but the batsmen at the other end were also scoring and that meant I didn't have to do anything rash. It's a tough one to take, the guys will be a bit distraught. We've worked so hard and I think we feel we deserved a win in this World Cup. We've played some good cricket, but still a couple games to go. So, fingers crossed."
Kyle Coetzer is the Man of the Match

Coetzer's stirring knock of 156 turned out to be the highest individual score by a player from Scotland in World Cups. He also became the first player from an Associate nation to notch up a 150. Incidentally, Scotland's total of 318 for 8 turned out to be their highest score in World Cups. Unfortunately for Scotland and Coetzer, it didn't prove to be enough on a flat deck. For Bangladesh, only Shakib bowled with good control, as rest of the bowlers struggled to stick to the old maxim of bowling line and length. Even in the slog overs, Bangladesh were below par. To make it worse for them, Anamul Haque suffered a dislocated shoulder while fielding. Bangladesh next will take on England in a key encounter in Adelaide. On the other hand, Scotland have the daunting task of taking on Sri Lanka in Hobart.

Earlier, Kyle Coetzer's splendid spread of stroke-play took Scotland to a sizeable total. Coetzer, who nowadays, plays for Northamptonshire, is known for his ability to pick the length quickly and essay shots on the back foot in the County circuit. With Bangladesh's seamers bowling short, Coetzer took heavy toll of some ordinary bowling to compose a ton. Once he reached a superbly paced hundred by thumping Rubel Hossain for a six, he provided the impetus to the innings by smashing both Rubel and Mashrafe Mortaza to shreds. Matt Machan and Preston Mommsen also played useful hands.

If Tamim and Mahmudullah set a solid platform, then Rahim upped the tempo with a quickfire knock. The diminutive wicket-keeper batsman, Rahim, produced a fine exhibition of stroke-play. In particular, in the 37th over of the innings, Rahim showed his class by stepping out to Iain Wardlaw, the former Yorkshire seamer, to loft him over the long-off region for a six. However, Rahim, then gifted his wicket away as he was dismissed by Alasdair Evans for 60. Shakib Al Hasan and Sabbir Rahman though, held their nerve to steer Bangladesh to victory. This was the first time that Bangladesh scored over 300 runs in the history of the mega event. This is also the second highest run chase in World Cups. For Scotland, Josh Davey was the only bowler, who looked like a threat. He found a bit of movement in the air and off the track to snare a couple of wickets.

Tamim Iqbal's crunching knock of 95 and fifties by Mahmudullah, Mushfiqur Rahim and Shakib Al Hasan helped Bangladesh to overhaul the stiff target. Tamim played a slew of magnificent cover-drives to put Bangladesh in the ascendancy. After Soumya Sarkar was caught down the leg-side, it was Tamim who opened up his shoulders to thread the minutest of gaps through the off-side with needlepoint precision and thwack a volley of eye-catching shots. Mahmudullah too played his part with a fine fifty. The 139-run stand for the second wicket between Tamim and Mahmudullah was the highest partnership for any wicket for Bangladesh in World Cups. Interestingly, Tamim's innings of 95 is now the highest individual score by a batsman from Bangladesh in World Cups.

48.1   Iain Wardlaw to Shakib, FOUR, that's it! Bangladesh win by 6 wickets and put more pressure on England. This is their highest successful run chase in ODIs and it is also the second highest run chase in World Cup history. Full and wide outside off stump, Shakib takes a step forward, slices it over backward point and signs off in style. He gets to his 28th ODI fifty as well. Rahman congratulates Shakib for reaching the milestone
47.6   Alasdair Evans to S Rahman, no run, it's clear, Rahman wants Shakib to get the fifty. Back of a length outside off stump, Rahman defends off the back foot
47.5   Alasdair Evans to S Rahman, no run, full and outside off stump, Rahman defends off the front foot. Maybe, he wants Shakib to get to fifty

47.4   Alasdair Evans to S Rahman, FOUR, cracking shot! Full and in the slot, Rahman doesn't try to over-hit the ball, just drives it wide of the man at extra-cover and mid-off had no chance. The scores are level
47.3   Alasdair Evans to S Rahman, no run, short and outside off stump, Rahman pulls it straight to mid-wicket
47.2   Alasdair Evans to Shakib, 1 run, short and down the leg-side, Shakib helps it down to fine leg
47.1   Alasdair Evans to Shakib, FOUR, low full toss and outside off stump, Shakib crashes it through cover and it runs away to the boundary. Bangladesh are just a hit away now
Alasdair Evans [9.0-1-58-1] is back into the attack
Bangladesh need just 10 runs off 18 balls.
46.6   Iain Wardlaw to S Rahman, 2 runs, low full toss on the leg stump, Rahman flicks it to mid-wicket
46.5   Iain Wardlaw to Shakib, 1 run, slower ball outside off stump, Shakib walks forward and jams it out towards short cover
46.4   Iain Wardlaw to Shakib, FOUR, it's a low full toss and Shakib has smashed this straight down the ground. Both long-off and long-on had no chance
46.3   Iain Wardlaw to Shakib, no run, yorker outside off stump, Shakib squeezes it out to the keeper
46.2   Iain Wardlaw to Shakib, no run, low full toss, the slower ball in fact, Shakib swings and hits it with one hand to backward square leg
46.1   Iain Wardlaw to S Rahman, 1 run, low full toss, driven to deep extra-cover
45.6   Davey to S Rahman, 1 run, almost a yorker, Rahman digs it out to long-on
45.5   Davey to Shakib, 1 run, yorker on the off stump, Shakib digs it out to third man. 300 is up for Bangladesh
45.4   Davey to S Rahman, 1 run, slower ball full and outside off stump, Rahman drives it to long-off
45.3   Davey to S Rahman, FOUR, it's all too easy now! Low full toss outside off stump, Rahman lofts it handsomely over extra-cover for a one-bounce four. Fifty partnership comes up off 45 balls
45.2   Davey to S Rahman, FOUR, full and on the leg stump, Rahman flicks it along the ground past the man at short fine leg, deep square leg runs to his right but he had no chance
45.1   Davey to Shakib, 1 run, misses the yorker and bowls a full toss, Shakib drives it to sweeper cover
44.6   Iain Wardlaw to S Rahman, no run, yorker on the stumps, Rahman digs it out, the bowler dives to his right and stops the ball
44.5   Iain Wardlaw to Shakib, 1 run, full and outside off stump, Shakib drills it wide of long-on
44.4   Iain Wardlaw to S Rahman, 1 run, full and outside off stump, Rahman drives it along the ground to long-off
44.3   Iain Wardlaw to S Rahman, no run, full and outside off stump, Rahman drives it to short cover, who dives to his right and stops the ball
44.2   Iain Wardlaw to S Rahman, no run, good length delivery outside off stump, Rahman tries to dab it down to third man and misses
44.1   Iain Wardlaw to S Rahman, 2 runs, low full toss on the off stump, Rahman works it to mid-wicket, calls for two and makes his ground comfortably
Iain Wardlaw [7.0-0-59-1] is back into the attack

43.6   Davey to Shakib, SIX, oh my word! He's given it all. Full and in the slot, Shakib clears his front leg out of the way and goes baanngggg, over mid-wicket and sends it into the stands. This is well within Bangladesh's reach now
43.5   Davey to Shakib, no run, very full again from Davey, Shakib keeps it out
43.4   Davey to Shakib, no run, yorker outside off stump, Shakib digs it out
43.3   Davey to S Rahman, 1 run, full and wide outside off stump, Rahman squeezes it out square of the wicket on the off-side
Chants of "Bangladesh, Bangladesh" are doing the rounds.
43.2   Davey to S Rahman, no run, good length delivery on the stumps, Rahman defends
43.1   Davey to Shakib, 1 run, full and wide outside off stump, Shakib reaches out and drives it to sweeper cover
Josh Davey [8.0-0-48-2] is back into the attack
Haq ends 10-0-49-0. Bangladesh need 42 off 42.
42.6   Haq to S Rahman, no run, Rahman drives hard again, Haq stops it to his right in his followthrough and stares at the batsman

42.5   Haq to S Rahman, SIX, oh he's hit that onto the roof and it's out of the ground! Floated up from Haq, Rahman dances down the track, gets to the pitch of the ball and smacks it over long-on for a 97-metre hit. New balls please!

42.4   Haq to S Rahman, 2 runs, 'catch it' is the call as Rahman pulls uppishly, the ball goes to the right of mid-wicket, oh a brilliant save in the deep diving to his left from Evans. He dived full length and somehow managed to stop it with his left hand
42.3   Haq to S Rahman, no run, very full, Rahman drills it back to the bowler, who dives to his right and stops the ball
42.2   Haq to S Rahman, no run, tossed up on the off stump, Rahman defends off the front foot
42.1   Haq to Shakib, 1 run, tossed up outside off stump, Shakib drives it square of the wicket on the off-side
Now we see a few smiling faces in the Bangladeshi dressing room after that over. It's 51 needed off 48 now.
41.6   Alasdair Evans to S Rahman, no run, on the off stump, knocked to mid-wicket
41.5   Alasdair Evans to S Rahman, no run, short of length delivery outside off stump, Rahman defends into the off-side

41.4   Alasdair Evans to S Rahman, SIX, that's a powerful blow and this will make him feel a lot more confident. Too short from Evans, not fast enough to trouble the batsman, Rahman rocks back and pulls easily over deep mid-wicket
41.3   Alasdair Evans to Shakib, 1 run, short of length delivery down the leg-side, Shakib knocks it to backward square leg
41.2   Alasdair Evans to Shakib, no run, short of length delivery outside off stump, Shakib advances and tries to hit it hard, but mistimes it back to the bowler, who jumps and half-stops the ball

41.1   Alasdair Evans to Shakib, FOUR, it's a poor ball and it releases all the pressure. Short and down the leg-side, Shakib rocks back and pulls it behind square on the on-side and fine leg had no chance
The Bangladeshi dressing room looks very tensed.
40.6   Haq to Shakib, 1 run, stays leg-side of the ball and drives the flighted delivery along the ground to deep cover
40.5   Haq to S Rahman, 1 run, nice and slower through the air, Rahman steps out and drives it along the ground to long-off
40.4   Haq to S Rahman, no run, goes on the back foot and looks to punch hard, but mistimes it back to the bowler
40.3   Haq to Shakib, 1 run, tossed up just outside off stump, Shakib turns it to long-on
40.2   Haq to S Rahman, 1 run, steps out and drives the flighted delivery along the ground to long-on
40.1   Haq to Shakib, 1 run, too short and too slow from Haq, Shakib pulls it to long-on

Bangladesh have scored 35/1 in the 5-over batting powerplay. Good comeback from Scotland considering that the first two overs costed them 25 runs. Shakib Al Hasan has been off strike for 13 balls now.
39.6   Alasdair Evans to S Rahman, no run, short of length delivery just outside off stump, Rahman knocks it to mid-on
39.5   Alasdair Evans to S Rahman, no run, good length delivery just outside off stump, Rahman defends off the front foot

39.4   Alasdair Evans to S Rahman, FOUR, outside edge and oh no! There was a man at slip the previous ball but Mommsen moved him to mid-wicket for this ball. This short of length delivery nips away slightly, Rahman looks to defend, gets a thick edge and it runs away to the third man boundary

39.3   Alasdair Evans to S Rahman, no run, oh he's almost dragged that on! The pressure is on Bangladesh now! Short of a length delivery outside off stump, Rahman goes for the pull but gets an inside edge onto pad
39.2   Alasdair Evans to S Rahman, no run, good length delivery just outside off stump, Rahman defends it to backward point
39.1   Alasdair Evans to S Rahman, no run, short of length delivery outside off stump, Rahman mistimes the pull to mid-on
An excellent over from Haq, just one run in it. This is just what Scotland wanted after removing Rahim. One slip in place now.
38.6   Haq to S Rahman, 1 run, on the off stump, Rahman turns it to short mid-wicket
38.5   Haq to S Rahman, no run, slower through the air, Rahman defends
38.4   Haq to S Rahman, no run, flatter delivery outside off stump, Rahman punches it to cover
38.3   Haq to S Rahman, no run, allows the ball to spin back in and works this flighted delivery to square leg
38.2   Haq to S Rahman, no run, tossed up just outside off stump, Rahman defends
38.1   Haq to S Rahman, no run, flighted delivery on the off stump, Rahman drives, the bowler makes a good diving save to his right
Majid Haq [7.0-0-34-0] is back into the attack
Sabbir Rahman, right handed bat, comes to the crease
Alright, 72 runs needed off 72 balls. Can Scotland pull things back with a couple of quick wickets? Remember, Anamul cannot bat and Bangladesh are a batsman down.

37.6   Alasdair Evans to Rahim, out Caught by MacLeod!! Oh this is a big wicket for Scotland. Rahim has thrown it away. A needless shot! Slower ball on the off stump, Rahim tries to go over mid-wicket, but gets it on the outside half of the bat, the ball goes high in the air, mid-on keeps his eyes on the ball runs back and takes a good catch. Rahim c MacLeod b Alasdair Evans 60(42) [4s-6 6s-2]
Alasdair Evans to Rahim, THATS OUT!! Caught!!
37.5   Alasdair Evans to Shakib, 1 run, this time he cuts it very late to third man

37.4   Alasdair Evans to Shakib, no run, has the keeper dropped Shakib? He's feeling the pain as it hit his fingertips. Short of a length delivery outside off stump, Shakib misses the cut. Shakib is disappointed that he didn't cut that for four
37.3   Alasdair Evans to Rahim, 1 run, slower ball wide outside off stump, Rahim cuts it to sweeper cover
37.2   Alasdair Evans to Shakib, 1 run, down the leg-side, tucked to backward square leg
37.1   Alasdair Evans to Shakib, 2 runs, short ball, no pace on the ball, Shakib pulls it to deep mid-wicket
Alasdair Evans [6.0-1-38-0] is back into the attack
Bangladesh have scored 25 runs off the first 2 overs of the batting powerplay.
36.6   Iain Wardlaw to Rahim, 2 runs, oh he's forehanded that pull shot, he keeps it along the ground, mid-on runs back and keeps it down to two

36.5   Iain Wardlaw to Rahim, FOUR, has that gone all the way? It has just bounced inside! Poor ball, short and wide outside off stump, Rahim waits and cuts fiercely over backward point, the ball almost goes all the way

36.4   Iain Wardlaw to Rahim, SIX, that's a magnificent shot and what a way to bring up his 20th ODI fifty. Length ball outside off stump, Rahim steps out and lofts it high over long-off. No great celebrations from Rahim, he knows that the job is not done yet
36.3   Iain Wardlaw to Shakib, 1 run, on the leg stump, Shakib pulls it to deep backward square leg
36.2   Iain Wardlaw to Shakib, no run, short of length delivery down the leg-side, Shakib inside-edges the pull onto thigh pad, the ball almost rolls back onto the stumps
36.2   Iain Wardlaw to Shakib, wide, bad ball, down the leg-side, Shakib tries to help it away but misses. A fine little tickle would have been four
36.1   Iain Wardlaw to Rahim, 1 run, full and on the leg stump, Rahim taps it to mid-on and sets off
Iain Wardlaw [6.0-0-44-1] is back into the attack
35.6   Davey to Shakib, FOUR, short ball on the leg stump, Shakib rocks back and pulls it over the infield to the deep mid-wicket fence. Good start to the powerplay for Bangladesh
35.5   Davey to Rahim, 1 run, in the air but doesn't carry to deep mid-wicket. Slower ball on the stumps, Rahim slog-sweeps it to mid-wicket
35.4   Davey to Shakib, 1 run, short of length delivery outside off stump, Shakib cuts it to sweeper cover
35.3   Davey to Shakib, 2 runs, advances and drives, the fielder at mid-off fumbles to allow the extra run
35.2   Davey to Rahim, 1 run, short of length delivery from Davey, Rahim taps it to short cover
35.1   Davey to Shakib, 1 run, guided away to third man
Batting powerplay has been enforced. Umpire Bruce Oxenford swung his arms so fast there while signalling the start of the powerplay.
34.6   Machan to Shakib, 1 run, flatter ball, punched to sweeper cover
34.5   Machan to Shakib, no run, flatter delivery on the off stump, Shakib mistimes the pull to short mid-wicket
34.4   Machan to Rahim, 1 run, pushed away to long-on
34.3   Machan to Rahim, FOUR, too short and there is no protection in the deep. Short and just outside off stump, Rahim rocks back and cuts, beats the diving fielder at cover

34.2   Machan to Rahim, no run, in the airrrrr and just short of the bowler. Rahim closes the face of the bat a bit too early in trying to flick, the flatter ball takes the leading edge, Machan runs forward and puts in the dive to his right but it doesn't carry
34.1   Machan to Shakib, 1 run, on the leg stump, pulled to backward square leg
33.6   Davey to Rahim, no run, short of length delivery outside off stump, Rahim hops and defends

33.5   Davey to Rahim, no run, oops! This could be a run-out, but Rahim escapes. Short slower ball, Rahim goes early into the pull, the ball rolls towards point off the toe-end of the bat, Rahim takes off for a run, but Shakib says no, Rahim slips while turning back, the fielder has a shy but misses. Rahim crawls back into the crease. He was a goner if it was a direct-hit
33.4   Davey to Rahim, no run, cuts nicely but straight to backward point
33.3   Davey to Shakib, 1 run, full and outside off stump, Shakib drives uppishly to deep extra-cover
33.2   Davey to Rahim, 1 run, goes on the back foot and punches the short of length delivery to sweeper cover
33.1   Davey to Rahim, no run, short of length delivery just outside off stump, Rahim taps it to backward point and looks for a run, but Shakib says no

Drinks are on the field now. Bangladesh are placed comfortably at the moment, but the wickets of Tamim and Mahmudullah have pegged them back slightly. However, the experienced duo of Rahim and Shakib are at the crease and Scotland will have to remove both very soon to have a chance of winning this game. We are heading towards a tight finish.

32.5   Machan to Rahim, 1 run, flatter and on the off stump, knocked to mid-wicket
32.4   Machan to Rahim, no run, short and outside off stump, Rahim cuts it to point
32.3   Machan to Shakib, 1 run, spinning away outside off stump, Shakib drives it square of the wicket on the off-side
32.2   Machan to Rahim, 1 run, tossed up outside off stump, Rahim drives it to long-on
32.1   Machan to Shakib, 1 run, tossed up outside off stump, Shakib drives it to cover
Matt Machan [5.0-0-34-0] is back into the attack
31.6   Davey to Shakib, 1 run, uppish but safe! Short and on the off stump, Shakib mistimes the pull to deep square leg
31.6   Davey to Shakib, wide, and again! A repeat of the previous ball, but it was further down the leg-side
31.6   Davey to Shakib, wide, down the leg-side, Shakib fails to help it on its way
31.5   Davey to Shakib, no run, around the off stump, defended off the back foot

Shakib Al Hasan, left handed bat, comes to the crease

31.3   Davey to Tamim, out Lbw!! Absolute waste of a review. That looked very out to the naked eye. Anyway, well played Tamim Iqbal. He's set the base with a fine knock. Good length delivery pitching around middle and leg, the ball nips back in slightly and hits Tamim on the front pad as he fails to connect with the drive. The impact was on middle and it was going on to hit middle stump. The umpire had no hesitation in his mind and put his finger up in a flash. Timely wicket for Scotland this. Tamim lbw b Davey 95(100) [4s-9 6s-1]
Davey to Tamim, THATS OUT!! Lbw!!

Tamim has been given OUT LBW. He talks to Rahim and decides to review. That looked pretty out. If there is no edge, that's plumb. Snicko says no bat involved. I am afraid he has to go. Pitches in-line, impact in-line and hitting the stumps.
31.2   Davey to Tamim, 2 runs, shortish and on the leg stump, Tamim pulls it to deep backward square leg, Evans makes a good sliding save to his left
31.1   Davey to Tamim, no run, mistimes the punch to cover
Josh Davey [5.0-0-31-1] is back into the attack
Umpire Bruce Oxenford has a long chat with Scotland captain Mommsen. Not sure why though!
30.6   Haq to Rahim, no run, comes down the track but was not upto the pitch of the ball, ends up defending off the inside half of the bat
30.5   Haq to Rahim, no run, floated up on off, Rahim defends off the front foot

30.2   Haq to Rahim, no run, good effort from the fielder, it was short and wide outside off, Rahim cuts it fiercely, but the fielder at cover-point dives to his left and makes a stunning stop, saved four for his team, the batsmen couldn't even take a single

30.1   Haq to Rahim, FOUR, 50 of the partnership comes up with this boundary, it was floated up outside off, Rahim gives the charge and loft-drives it inside out wide of mid-off and the ball runs away to the fence
Majid Haq [6.0-0-26-0] is back into the attack
29.6   Machan to Rahim, 1 run, on the off stump, pushed to long-on

29.4   Machan to Rahim, SIX, that is a very well connected slog-sweep from the former Bangladeshi skipper. Flighted delivery on the leg stump, Rahim gets down on one knee and sends it soaring over deep mid-wicket

28.6   Alasdair Evans to Rahim, 2 runs, shortish and on the stumps, Rahim pulls it to deep mid-wicket
28.5   Alasdair Evans to Rahim, no run, on a length and outside off stump, punched to cover. The fielder has a needless shy at the bowler's end, lucky that it didn't deflect away to the boundary

28.3   Alasdair Evans to Rahim, 2 runs, down the leg-side, Rahim tickles it down to fine leg, where Davey makes a diving save
28.2   Alasdair Evans to Rahim, no run, fullish and outside off stump, Rahim defends

27.5   Machan to Tamim, no run, flighted delivery on the stumps, Tamim knocks it into the on-side

Tamim Iqbal is stretching his legs. Maybe he's struggling with cramps. Oh ho! He's angry with the bloke who brought in a drink. He wants a different drink. The physio runs out and stretches Tamim's left leg. He's fine now and we are ready to go.

27.3   Machan to Tamim, no run, fullish and sliding into the left-hander, Tamim gets an inside edge that rolls towards square leg

27.1   Machan to Rahim, FOUR, full and outside off stump, Rahim drives nicely off the front foot, deep point runs to his right and puts in the dive but the ball wins the race

Welcome back. The players are walking out to the middle. It is going to be some run-chase if Bangladesh are to overhaul the Scottish total. On the other hand, if Scotland manages to win this game, it will be their first ever win in World Cups. Soumya Sarkar will open with Tamim Iqbal as Anamul Haque injured his shoulder while fielding

On the other hand, Bangladesh have been well below par. Their bowlers couldn't maintain line and length and the fielding was average. Bangladesh's bowling in the slog overs was poor. In fact, only Shakib was able to keep the opposition batsmen in check by bowling with good control. To make it worse for them, Anamul Haque, the opener, seemed to have dislocated his shoulder while looking to save a boundary. It is a flat deck and Bangladesh can still chase down this target, but we certainly have a match on our hands.

Machan and Scotland's captain, Mommsen, played with composure too. It was Machan, who helped Coetzer to construct a fine partnership of 78 after they lost a couple of wickets against the new ball. Mommsen came into the tournament on the back of being adjudged as the ICC Associate and Affiliate Cricketer of the Year for his stellar performances in World Cup Qualifiers held in New Zealand in 2014, but hasn't exactly been in good form in the mega event. However, today, he proved his worth by playing power-packed shots and twinned it by cleverly rotating the strike.

Despite losing the wickets of Calum MacLeod and Hamish Gardiner upfront, Coetzer played with a dash of fearlessness. In particular, when Bangladesh's seamers bowled short, Coetzer took heavy toll of it by collecting boundaries. Ever since his debut for Durham in 2004, Coetzer is known for his ability to play horizontal-bat shots in England's domestic circuit. However, Bangladesh's seamers didn't look to bring Coetzer forward. Coetzer also showed his class against the wily spinner Shakib Al Hasan by slog sweeping him for a six. To make it a great day for Coetzer, he reached his hundred by lofting Rubel Hossain over the long-on region for a six. Once Coetzer reached his ton, he pressed the accelerator pedal and hammered Rubel for 18 runs in a single over and followed it up by thwacking Mashrafe Mortaza all over the park in the 42nd over of the innings. After composing a spellbinding knock, he was eventually, dismissed by Nasir Hossain. Coetzer now holds the record for the highest individual score by a Scottish player in World Cups. Incidentally, he is now the first player from Scotland to notch up a hundred in World Cups. He also became the first Associate batsman to amass a 150 in World Cups.

On the back of Kyle Coetzer's sparkling knock of 156, and fine hands played by Matt Machan and Preston Mommsen, Scotland notched up a sizeable total on the board. Scotland's score of 318 for 8 turned out to be their highest total in the history of the World Cup. After Bangladesh won the toss and surprisingly, elected to bowl first on an easy paced wicket, it was Coetzer, who shone brightly by cracking a wide array of shots, especially on the back foot.

Coetzer's partner at the other end, Machan, also looked in fine touch as he bisected the gaps square of the wicket on either side to collect runs. However, he then offered a simple caught and bowled chance to Sabbir Rahman and was dismissed. It was a soft dismissal, but the bowler deserves the credit for slowing it up in the air. From Bangladesh's point of view, it has to be said that their fielding has again been a let down. To make it worse for them, Anamul Haque seemed to have dislocated his shoulder, while looking to save a boundary.

Here is Bharath Ramaraj's analysis of the last 14 overs: Kyle Coetzer and Matt Machan stitched a key partnership to help Scotland make a smart recovery. Bangladesh's pacers didn't help their cause by not bowling a fuller length to Coetzer. Coetzer certainly likes to stay back. When Mortaza bowled a back of a length delivery in the 23rd over of the innings, Coetzer duly took advantage of it by smashing him for a boundary. He also slog swept Shakib Al Hasan for a six. Coetzer, then reached his fifty in just 54 balls.

The Australian born top-order batsman, Hamish Gardiner, then looked in decent touch, especially when Bangladesh's pacers bowled short. Unfortunately, he lost his wicket to Taskin Ahmed. It was a short and wide delivery and asking to be dispatched to the boundary, but Garidner hit it straight to Soumya Sarkar at cover-point. It is up to Scotland's key batsmen, Kyle Coetzer and Sussex's Matt Machan to construct a partnership and take them to a position of strength. Interestingly, for Bangladesh, Shakib Al Hasan shared the new ball with Mortaza.

Here is Bharath Ramaraj's analysis of the first 17 overs: Calum MacLeod, who has been in poor form in this World Cup started on a good note by scoring a flurry of boundaries in the first over of the innings bowled by Mashrafe Mortaza. However, Mortaza came back strongly to bowl a short of length delivery to induce a leading edge and snare his wicket. MacLeod paid the price for getting caught in the crease.
Time for a drinks break!

0.3   Mortaza to MacLeod, no run, drags the length back around off, MacLeod prefers to stay in the crease and dabs it towards the slip cordon

0.2   Mortaza to MacLeod, FOUR, lovely shot! That should get him going. It was an overpitched delivery just outside off, MacLeod leans forward and caresses the drive through extra cover. The lightning fast outfield takes it to the fence

0.1   Mortaza to Coetzer, 1 run, bit of swing for Mortaza, it is too far outside off and shapes away further, Coetzer throws his bat at that and gets a thick outside edge down to third man. He had to reach out for that
Coetzer and MacLeod are at the crease. Coetzer is on strike. Mortaza will open the attack

Both teams line-up for their respective national anthems. It's the Scottish anthem that is played first followed by the Bangladeshi anthem. Mortaza gathers his men around and has a last minute pep talk before they take the field. The Scottish openers make their way out to the middle. Mortaza has the new cherry in his hand. Umpire Fry says "Let's play". Here we go...

Pitch Report: "It's a fresh pitch and it's the third game here. It's a similar looking pitch as the first two games. There's a heck of a lot of grass there but essentially it is dead grass. I think what this grass will do is just help the ball to come through. There will be a bit of carry and the pitch will get better through the day. Expect the clouds to stay away," reckons Nick Knight
Teams:
Scotland (Playing XI): Kyle Coetzer, Calum MacLeod, Hamish Gardiner, Matt Machan, Preston Mommsen(c), Richie Berrington, Matthew Cross(w), Josh Davey, Majid Haq, Alasdair Evans, Iain Wardlaw
Bangladesh (Playing XI): Anamul Haque, Tamim Iqbal, Soumya Sarkar, Mahmudullah, Shakib Al Hasan, Mushfiqur Rahim(w), Nasir Hossain, Sabbir Rahman, Mashrafe Mortaza(c), Rubel Hossain, Taskin Ahmed
Bangladesh have won the toss and have opted to field

Mortaza: "It was a tough match against Sri Lanka. We had a 7 day break and we had a good preparation. We will bowl first. Looks like there is moisture in the wicket and the ball will swing a bit. Hopefully, we will restrict them to a good total that we can chase down. Bowling was not upto the mark in the last match, hopefully we will come back nicely in this match. The top-order will hopefully, make a comeback. One change, Mominul is not there in the team and Nasir Hossain comes back."

Mommsen: "That was a difficult one to take (the game against Afghanistan). But, we had a few days off and it is brilliant to be at Nelson, taking the scenery and get refreshed. We are ready to go today. We would have bowled first as well. But, I think at the same time it looks like a good cricket wicket. Hopefully, we can put the runs on the board and put them under pressure. That is going to be an important phase today and make sure we get through the new ball. The focus will be on the middle overs and make sure we set-up the back end of the innings. We wanted to approach every game the same. Bangladesh, we know we are capable of beating, we have beaten them in the past. So, we want to put in a good performance today. We got the same XI."

Head-to-Head: These two teams have faced each other 4 times, Bangladesh winning 3 and the other being washed out. However, this is the first time they are meeting in a World Cup. So, who will come out on top? Stay tuned as the toss is not far away...
Scotland

Meanwhile, Scotland started the tournament with some spirited performance versus New Zealand. After being bowled for 142, they took 7 Kiwi wickets and gave them a run for their money. Against England, they managed to pull things back after Mooen Ali's hundred, but a target of 304 was beyond their reach. Their best chance came in the previous game against Afghanistan. The two Associates were involved in a thriller, which saw the Asian side chasing 210 down, after being 97/7 at one stage. It was a heartbreak for the Scottish players.

Carrying the intensity through the 100 overs has been a problem for the Associate teams. Scotland have managed to stay in the game for 35-40 overs, but have not been able to seize the key moments in the game. The bowling attack looks decent with Wardlaw, Davey and Evans bowling with a lot of discipline. Their batsmen Coetzer, Machan, Mommsen and Berrington have all contributed at some point, but are not consistent. Their next two games are against Sri Lanka and Australia, which means this is the best chance to register their maiden World Cup win.
Bangladesh

Bangladesh started their campaign with a win over Afghanistan. Fifties from Shakib and Mushfiqur helped them post 267 on the board. Then, the bowlers rolled the opposition over for 162, with captain Mortaza leading from the front with 3 wickets. Their second game versus Australia was abandoned without a ball being bowled, thanks to cyclone Marcia. The last game that they played was against Sri Lanka. Dilshan and Sanga scored tons and put the game out of their reach. Chasing a target of 333, Bangladesh folded for 240.

There are plenty of concerns for the Bangladeshi side. The form of Tamim and Anamul is a worrying factor. Their dependency on Shakib and Mushfiqur to score the runs is clearly seen. They need the rest of the batters to show the application and they need to do it quickly if they want to qualify for the quarter-finals. Two wins out of the remaining three games will give them a realistic chance entering the final 8, but their next two games are against England and New Zealand. So, this is a crucial encounter for them.

08:45 Local Time, 20:45 GMT, 02:15 IST: Scotland come into this game still searching for their first World Cup win. They have so far played 11 matches and are yet to succeed. This will be their best chance to register their maiden World Cup victory. They face off Bangladesh, who are the only Test playing nation they have beaten - in a T20I in 2012. That should give them the confidence when they take on the Asian side. Let us have a look as to how these two teams have fared so far in the tournament.

Preview

For Bangladesh to have any chance to make it to the quarter-finals of the ICC Cricket World Cup 2015, they will have to win two of their next three fixtures. After opening their campaign with an easy win against Afghanistan, they got a bonus point courtesy a washout against Australia; but a pasting at the hands of Sri Lanka would have had the ninth-ranked ODI team thinking. But, up against Scotland at the Saxton Oval, the Asian team will be hoping to stay alive in race for the knockout stage, before they face off against much tougher opponents in England and New Zealand.

Scotland, on the other hand, are still looking for their first in this World Cup and after failing to clinch a thriller against Afghanistan, the match against Bangladesh provides them with the last realistic chance to open their account in the tournament, before taking on Sri Lanka and Australia. However, the Associates can take heart from the fact that it was here at the Saxton Oval that another Associate nation, Ireland, defeated West Indies in the fifth game of the competition. Also, Scotland's only win against a full-member nation was against Bangladesh in a T20I in 2012.

Venue: Saxton Oval, Nelson

Start: 03:30 IST

Weather: It will be mostly sunny with the temperatures vacillating between 19 and 27 degrees Celsius.

Team News:

Bangladesh

Despite the wavering forms of Tamim Iqbal and Anamul Haque, Bangladesh are not likely to tinker with the batting line-up, but they could add an extra spinner in the form of Arafat Sunny or Taijul Islam to exploit the Associate nation's weakness against slower bowlers.

Probable XI: 1 Tamim Iqbal, 2 Anamul Haque, 3 Soumya Sarkar, 4 Mahmudullah, 5 Shakib Al Hasan, 6 Mushfiqur Rahim (wk), 7 Sabbir Rahman, 8 Mominul Haque/Taijul Islam, 9 Mashrafe Mortaza (capt), 10 Taskin Ahmed, 11 Rubel Hossain

Scotland

Opener Calum MacLeod has had a horrific World Cup so far scoring just four runs from three innings, and it is likely that Scotland might bench him.

Probable XI: 1 Kyle Coetzer, 2 Calum MacLeod/Freddie Coleman, 3 Hamish Gardiner, 4 Matt Machan, 5 Preston Mommsen (capt), 6 Richie Berrington, 7 Matthew Cross (wk), 8 Josh Davey, 9 Majid Haq, 10 Alasdair Evans, 11 Iain Wardlaw.

Player to watch out for:

Allrounder Sakib al Hasan has been in good form with the bat for Bangladesh and his his left-arm spin will surely prove a handful for the Scots. For Scotland, Matt Machan and Richie Berrington have been the stand out players, and to counter the Bangladesh spinners, these two will have to bat out of their skin.

Quotes:

"We are expecting a full spin attack from the Bangladeshis or we're preparing for that at least," Scotland skipper Preston Mommsen.

"Yeah, we expect to win. When we lost, we also lost some confidence. So this is an opportunity to win this match and go with some confidence into the game against England," Bangladesh skipper Mashrafe Mortaza.

Stats and trivia:

The only win for Scotland against a full-member nation came against Bangladesh in a T20I in 2012

Bangladesh (From): Anamul Haque, Tamim Iqbal, Soumya Sarkar, Mahmudullah, Shakib Al Hasan, Mushfiqur Rahim(w), Sabbir Rahman, Taijul Islam, Mashrafe Mortaza(c), Rubel Hossain, Taskin Ahmed, Mominul Haque, Nasir Hossain, Arafat Sunny, Shafiul Islam
